DRC and M23 rebels sign ceasefire deal
subhead: The Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda-backed armed group M23 negotiated the deal in Qatar. It follows a separate agreement between the DRC and Rwanda.

title: Secondhand medals reveal existence of Russian intelligence cyber units
subhead: A new report has analyzed public images of medals from the 16th Center of the Federal Security Service (FSB), Russia's internal intelligence branch responsible for communications espionage, uncovering valuable information about its organization.

title: Avignon staging of Pelicot trial brings theater of the real to a new height
subhead: In 'Le Procès Pelicot,' Swiss director Milo Rau brought four months of the landmark Pelicot mass rape trial to the stage on Friday, July 18, with unflinching rigor and an avoidance of sensationalism.

title: Pier Paolo Pasolini's mysterious death continues to haunt Italy, 50 years on
subhead: The murder of the Italian writer and filmmaker on November 2, 1975, still raises many questions. Among those who have not given up on the case, lawyer Stefano Maccioni fought for years to have judicial proceedings reopened. Now, he places his hopes in the parliamentary inquiry committee that has just been created.

Between rationing and a collaborationist past, the first holidays for Vichy's children after World War II
subhead: 'The Summer of 1945' (5/6). In the aftermath of the war, the Vichy city council sought to restore the town's status as the 'capital of thermal spas.' At the same time, secular groups and religious institutions worked to offer children a summer break before the new school year began.

title: Early and intense wildfire season has arrived around the Mediterranean
subhead: As of July 8, some 214,000 hectares have been ravaged by flames in the European Union, more than double the average. Fires have broken out further north in Europe, and the eastern Mediterranean region has also been struck.
byline: By Maryline Baumard, Olivier Bonnel (Rome, correspondent), Nicolas Bourcier (Istanbul (Turkey) correspondent), Isabelle Piquer (Madrid (Spain) correspondent), Marina Rafenberg (Athens (Greece) correspondent) and Hélène Sallon (Beirut (Lebanon) correspondent)

title: These French villages have no more drinking water. The reason? PFAS pollution
subhead: Nearly 3,500 residents across 16 rural villages have been unable to drink tap water since July 10 due to a record-breaking contamination by PFAS, a group of toxic substances known as 'forever chemicals.'
byline: By Stéphane Mandard (Blagny, La Ferté-sur-Chiers, Villy, Han-lès-Juvigny and Stenay (eastern France), special correspondent)
